english: To remember; to recall (something that comes back to mind). Often used with を for the thing recalled.
japanese_example: <ruby>急<rt>きゅう</rt></ruby>に<ruby>昔<rt>むかし</rt></ruby>のことを<ruby>思<rt>おも</rt></ruby>い<ruby>出<rt>だ</rt></ruby>した。
english_example: I suddenly remembered something from long ago.

english: Midnight; the middle of the night. Used for time when people are normally asleep.
japanese_example: <ruby>夜中<rt>よなか</rt></ruby>に<ruby>電話<rt>でんわ</rt></ruby>が<ruby>鳴<rt>な</rt></ruby>って<ruby>目<rt>め</rt></ruby>が<ruby>覚<rt>さ</rt></ruby>めた。
english_example: The phone rang in the middle of the night and I woke up.

english: To wake up; to come to (from sleep, dream, drunkenness, etc.). Intransitive; contrasts with 起こす (to wake someone).
japanese_example: <ruby>悪夢<rt>あくむ</rt></ruby>で<ruby>目<rt>め</rt></ruby>が<ruby>覚<rt>さ</rt></ruby>めた。
english_example: I woke up from a nightmare.

english: Lead-colored; ashen gray (often describing a dull, heavy, ominous color like sky or complexion). Can carry a deathly/pale nuance.
japanese_example: <ruby>空<rt>そら</rt></ruby>は<ruby>鉛色<rt>なまりいろ</rt></ruby>で、<ruby>今<rt>いま</rt></ruby>にも<ruby>雨<rt>あめ</rt></ruby>が<ruby>降<rt>ふ</rt></ruby>りそうだ。
english_example: The sky was an ashen gray, and it looked like it would rain any moment.

english: To open (one’s eyes) wide. Often used for surprise, fear, or shock.
japanese_example: <ruby>彼女<rt>かのじょ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>目<rt>め</rt></ruby>を<ruby>見<rt>み</rt></ruby><ruby>開<rt>ひら</rt></ruby>いて<ruby>固<rt>かた</rt></ruby>まった。
english_example: She froze with her eyes wide open.

english: Terrifying; dreadful (common everyday adjective). More direct/common than 恐れる, which is a verb meaning “to fear.”
japanese_example: <ruby>恐<rt>おそ</rt></ruby>ろしい<ruby>音<rt>おと</rt></ruby>がして、<ruby>体<rt>からだ</rt></ruby>が<ruby>震<rt>ふる</rt></ruby>えた。
english_example: A terrifying sound came, and my body trembled.

english: Eye(s) (more literary/formal kanji than 目). Often appears in set phrases or written style.
japanese_example: <ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>の<ruby>眼<rt>め</rt></ruby>には<ruby>迷<rt>まよ</rt></ruby>いがなかった。
english_example: There was no hesitation in his eyes.

english: Absentmindedly; vaguely; dimly (mimetic adverb). Often in ぼんやりと; describes unfocused perception or thinking.
japanese_example: <ruby>窓<rt>まど</rt></ruby>の<ruby>外<rt>そと</rt></ruby>をぼんやりと<ruby>眺<rt>なが</rt></ruby>めていた。
english_example: I was absentmindedly gazing out the window.

english: To raise oneself; to sit up/get up (focuses on the whole self, not just the physical body). Contrast: 身体 is more purely physical.
japanese_example: <ruby>夜中<rt>よなか</rt></ruby>に<ruby>目<rt>め</rt></ruby>が<ruby>覚<rt>さ</rt></ruby>めて、そっと<ruby>身<rt>み</rt></ruby>を<ruby>起<rt>お</rt></ruby>こした。
english_example: I woke up in the middle of the night and quietly sat up.

english: To stare back; to return someone’s gaze (compound using 返す “to do back/return”).
japanese_example: <ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>が<ruby>見<rt>み</rt></ruby>てきたので、<ruby>私<rt>わたし</rt></ruby>も<ruby>見<rt>み</rt></ruby>つめ<ruby>返<rt>かえ</rt></ruby>した。
english_example: He stared at me, so I stared back.

english: Leaf/leaves (more formal; often used in nature descriptions like leaves falling). More casual/specific is 葉っぱ.
japanese_example: <ruby>風<rt>かぜ</rt></ruby>で<ruby>葉<rt>は</rt></ruby>がひらひらと<ruby>落<rt>お</rt></ruby>ちた。
english_example: The leaves fluttered down in the wind.

english: To appear; to show up; to emerge (intransitive). Used for people, things, signs, patterns, etc.
japanese_example: <ruby>向<rt>む</rt></ruby>こうから<ruby>突然<rt>とつぜん</rt></ruby><ruby>人影<rt>ひとかげ</rt></ruby>が<ruby>現<rt>あらわ</rt></ruby>れた。
english_example: A figure suddenly appeared from the other side.

english: The other side; over there; beyond (place or direction). Often contrasted with こちら/こっち.
japanese_example: <ruby>川<rt>かわ</rt></ruby>の<ruby>向<rt>む</rt></ruby>こうに<ruby>駅<rt>えき</rt></ruby>がある。
english_example: The station is on the other side of the river.

english: To drift; to float; to hang in the air (smell, mood, smoke, etc.). Often used for something spreading subtly.
japanese_example: <ruby>部屋<rt>へや</rt></ruby>にコーヒーの<ruby>香<rt>かお</rt></ruby>りが<ruby>漂<rt>ただよ</rt></ruby>っていた。
english_example: The smell of coffee was drifting through the room.

english: Drip-drop; dripping heavily (mimetic). Often for liquid falling in thick drops, like water or sweat.
japanese_example: <ruby>汗<rt>あせ</rt></ruby>がボタボタ<ruby>床<rt>ゆか</rt></ruby>に<ruby>落<rt>お</rt></ruby>ちた。
english_example: Sweat dripped heavily onto the floor.

english: To put a tune/intonation on; to speak or sing in a sing-song way. Often implies unnatural or teasing cadence.
japanese_example: <ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>はわざと<ruby>節<rt>ふし</rt></ruby>をつけて<ruby>名<rt>な</rt></ruby>まえを<ruby>呼<rt>よ</rt></ruby>んだ。
english_example: He deliberately called my name in a sing-song voice.

english: To blink (repeatedly), often in surprise or confusion (colloquial mimetic + する).
japanese_example: <ruby>彼女<rt>かのじょ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>驚<rt>おどろ</rt></ruby>いて<ruby>目<rt>め</rt></ruby>をパチクリした。
english_example: She blinked in surprise.

english: To disappear; to go out (lights, fire); to vanish. Intransitive.
japanese_example: <ruby>曲<rt>ま</rt></ruby>がり<ruby>角<rt>かど</rt></ruby>で<ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>の<ruby>姿<rt>すがた</rt></ruby>が<ruby>消<rt>き</rt></ruby>えた。
english_example: His figure disappeared around the corner.

english: The place where something was (あった = existed/was located). Used to refer back to a previous location.
japanese_example: <ruby>鍵<rt>かぎ</rt></ruby>はさっきあったところに<ruby>戻<rt>もど</rt></ruby>しておいた。
english_example: I put the key back where it was earlier.

english: Without taking one’s eyes off (keeping constant watch). Pattern: 目を離す (to look away) + ずに (without doing).
japanese_example: <ruby>目<rt>め</rt></ruby>を<ruby>離<rt>はな</rt></ruby>さずに<ruby>子<rt>こ</rt></ruby>どもを<ruby>見守<rt>みまも</rt></ruby>った。
english_example: I watched the child without taking my eyes off them.

english: Right next to; very close by (distance). Often used with に/で: すぐそばに.
japanese_example: <ruby>駅<rt>えき</rt></ruby>のすぐそばに<ruby>小<rt>ちい</rt></ruby>さな<ruby>店<rt>みせ</rt></ruby>がある。
english_example: There’s a small shop right next to the station.

english: Casual contraction of それはよかった: “That’s good to hear / I’m glad.” Often used as a quick reaction in conversation.
japanese_example: お<ruby>父<rt>とう</rt></ruby>さん、<ruby>退院<rt>たいいん</rt></ruby>したの？ そりゃよかった。
english_example: Your dad got discharged from the hospital? That’s great to hear.

english: Finally; at last (after a long time or difficulty). Often implies relief or that it took effort.
japanese_example: やっと<ruby>仕事<rt>しごと</rt></ruby>が<ruby>終<rt>お</rt></ruby>わった。
english_example: I finally finished work.

english: Day of the week (e.g., 月曜日). Often used with 何曜日 (what day).
japanese_example: <ruby>今日<rt>きょう</rt></ruby>は<ruby>何曜日<rt>なんようび</rt></ruby>ですか。
english_example: What day of the week is it today?

english: So that’s why it turned out that ~ / in other words, that means ~. って is casual quotation; 訳だ gives an explanatory “that’s the reason/logic.”
japanese_example: <ruby>電車<rt>でんしゃ</rt></ruby>が<ruby>止<rt>と</rt></ruby>まってたから、<ruby>遅<rt>おく</rt></ruby>れたって<ruby>訳<rt>わけ</rt></ruby>だ。
english_example: So the reason you were late is that the train was stopped.

english: To laugh in someone’s face (contemptuously). Literal “at the tip of the nose,” but idiomatically mocking someone directly.
japanese_example: <ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>私<rt>わたし</rt></ruby>の<ruby>提案<rt>ていあん</rt></ruby>を<ruby>鼻先<rt>はなさき</rt></ruby>で<ruby>笑<rt>わら</rt></ruby>った。
english_example: He laughed in my face at my suggestion.

english: Weird; goofy; odd (colloquial adjective modifying nouns). Similar to 変な but more playful/childish tone.
japanese_example: <ruby>へんてこりん</ruby>な<ruby>帽子<rt>ぼうし</rt></ruby>をかぶって<ruby>歩<rt>ある</rt></ruby>いていた。
english_example: They were walking around wearing a goofy hat.

english: Mother (as a role/figure; more formal than お母さん, often used in narration or social contexts).
japanese_example: <ruby>母親<rt>ははおや</rt></ruby>として<ruby>何<rt>なに</rt></ruby>ができるか<ruby>考<rt>かんが</rt></ruby>えた。
english_example: I thought about what I could do as a mother.

english: Cold; chilly in attitude; emotionally distant (na-adjective). Often used for looks, voice, or reactions: 冷ややかな目.
japanese_example: <ruby>彼女<rt>かのじょ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>冷<rt>ひ</rt></ruby>ややかな<ruby>目<rt>め</rt></ruby>で<ruby>私<rt>わたし</rt></ruby>を<ruby>見<rt>み</rt></ruby>た。
english_example: She looked at me with cold eyes.
